an4.191:4.1: “Mendicants, you can expect four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.
an4.191:4.3: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:4.4: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired sayings, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and analyses.
an4.191:4.5: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well penetrated them by view.
an4.191:4.6: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:4.7: They’re happy there, and passages of the teaching come back to them.
an4.191:4.9: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:4.10: This is the first benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.
an4.191:5.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:5.2: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired sayings, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and analyses.
an4.191:5.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well penetrated them by view.
an4.191:5.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:5.5: They’re happy there, but passages of the teaching don’t come back to them.
an4.191:5.6: However, a mendicant with psychic powers, who has achieved mastery of the mind, teaches Dharma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:5.8: ‘I used to live the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’
an4.191:5.10: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:5.11: Suppose a person was an expert in the sound of drums.
an4.191:5.12: While travelling along a road they hear the sound of drums.
an4.191:5.13: They wouldn’t have any doubts or uncertainties about whether
an4.191:5.14: that was the sound of drums or not.
an4.191:5.15: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of drums.’
an4.191:5.16: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:5.19: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …
an4.191:5.25: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:5.26: This is the second benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.
an4.191:6.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:6.2: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired sayings, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and analyses.
an4.191:6.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well penetrated them by view.
an4.191:6.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:6.5: But passages of the teaching don’t come back to them when they’re happy, nor does a mendicant with psychic powers … teach Dharma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:6.6: However, a god teaches Dharma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:6.8: ‘I used to live the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’
an4.191:6.10: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:6.11: Suppose a person was an expert in the sound of horns.
an4.191:6.12: While travelling along a road they hear the sound of horns.
an4.191:6.13: They wouldn’t have any doubt about whether
an4.191:6.14: that was the sound of horns or not.
an4.191:6.15: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of horns.’
an4.191:6.16: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:6.19: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:6.25: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:6.26: This is the third benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.
an4.191:7.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:7.2: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired sayings, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and analyses.
an4.191:7.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well penetrated them by view.
an4.191:7.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:7.5: But passages of the Dharma don’t come back to them when they’re happy, and neither a mendicant with psychic powers … nor a god teaches Dharma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:7.6: But a being who has been reborn spontaneously reminds another such being:
an4.191:7.7: ‘Do you remember, good sir? Do you remember where we used to live the spiritual life?’
an4.191:7.11: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:7.12: Suppose there were two friends who had played together in the sand.
an4.191:7.13: Some time or other they’d meet.
an4.191:7.14: And one friend would say to the other:
an4.191:7.15: ‘Do you remember this, friend? Do you remember that, friend?’
an4.191:7.18: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:7.21: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:7.28: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:7.29: This is the fourth benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.
an4.191:7.30: You can expect these four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well penetrated by view.”
